column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0218] The ability to dramatically alter the tensile ratios also allows the production of very unique tissues.
#Text=For example, marketing research shows that there are minimum CD tensiles that the consumer associates with adequate strength.
#Text=In conventional CWP and TAD processes, this CD tensile strength defines the range of MD tensiles for acceptable product.
#Text=In some cases these conventional processes can produce a final product tensile ratio of about 1:1 (MD/CD=1.1).
#Text=The tensiles of the sheets exhibit a strong relationship to the softness of the sheets.
#Text=Sheets made using the present invention exhibit unexpected tensile strength behaviors.
#Text=For example, it is quite easy to produce sheets where the CD is twice the MD (MD/CD=0.5).

#Text=The high MD and CD stretch values that result from the fabric creping step allow efficient converting operation at tensile values far below what is expected from conventional tissues while maintaining the consumer perception of adequate strength.
#Text=A typical conventional sheet exhibits a sensory softness value of 18 at tensiles of 1600 by 700 grams or a GMT of 1060 grams.
#Text=With this invention, a sheet of similar weight could be made at tensiles of 600 by 600 by taking advantage of the stretch properties.
#Text=The sheet's 600 grams GMT would yield a basesheet with softness significantly above the value of 18.
#Text=Using this approach the amount of surface applied "softening and lotioning" ingredients could be significantly reduced.
#Text=For example, some products require as much as 40 lbs/ton of these ingredients.
#Text=Reducing them to some nominal value like 10 lbs/ton could save costs of at least $40 per ton and as much as $100/ ton of product.

#Text=[0219] The nature of the high MD stretch of the sheets made with the present invention also allows for the overall tensiles to be reduced to levels below that normally considered appropriate for reliable running on papermaking and converting machines.
#Text=For example, in the above example the 600.times.600 gram (MD/CD tensile) sheet could be reduced to levels typically seen in one of the two-plies of a two-ply product.
#Text=In this case, those tensiles values could be further reduced to something on the order of 400.times.400.

#Text=This reduction is possible only because of the very high MD stretch values that could be put into the sheet and make it very "elastic" and thus able to resist the snap breaks typically seen in sheets that are of lower stretch values.

#Text=In the practice of the present invention, dropping the tensiles to this low level can be accomplished with chemicals such as debonders and softeners thus making for a very soft, yet functional, tissue that can be made with a wide variety of different types of fibers, especially low-cost fibers.

#Text=[0220] Very strong, but soft tissue can be made using the process of the present invention because the observed bending stiffness of these sheets is very low due to the inherently low modulus values of the sheets with high stretch, both MD and CD.
#Text=Softness of the products can further be enhanced by proper fiber preparation.
#Text=Long fibers are important for strength generation but often contribute to stiffness and gritty feel.
#Text=This can be overcome in the process by refining the long fibers to a relatively low freeness value, preferably with minimal fiber shortening.
#Text=At the same time, hardwood (or softness) fibers could have debonder applied to them at relatively high consistencies in the stock preparation area.
#Text=This debonder addition should be sufficient to significantly reduce the handsheet tensile but not so high as to completely impede bonding.
#Text=Then these two fibers are combined either homogeneously or stratified in the headbox.
#Text=In this manner, the softwood fibers bond to form an open network of long fibers that exhibit high tensile and stretch.
#Text=The hardwood fibers preferentially bond to the long fiber network and not to themselves.
#Text=These debonded fibers attach on the outside of the sheet giving a luxurious tactile property while high tensiles are maintained.
#Text=In this process, the final tensile of the sheet will be controlled by the ratio of the softwood and hardwood fibers used.
#Text=The debonded outer surface minimizes the need to apply lotions and softeners while at the same time reducing the impact on the papermachine especially the dry creping step.
#Text=[0221] Similarly, premium tissue products can be produced using significant amounts of recycled fibers.
#Text=Since these fibers can be treated in ways similar to virgin fibers, these sheets exhibit high levels of softness while maintaining an environmentally friendly technology position.
#Text=[0222] Creping fabric designs can be changed to significantly alter the properties of the sheets.
#Text=For example, finer fabrics produce sheets with very smooth surface features but at lower caliper generation.
#Text=Coarser fabrics impart a stronger fabric pattern and are capable of producing higher caliper sheets exhibiting greater two-sidedness.
#Text=However, higher calipers allow for greater calendering to smooth the surface while maintaining the pattern.
#Text=In this manner, the invention gives the potential to produce soft, strong sheets with or without significant patterns in them.
